bibl.title: Military Orders for Aristides Agramonte, May 23, 1900

div1.p: Special Orders #74 relieves Agramonte from his duty as Acting Assistant Surgeon in Havana and transfers him to the Division Laboratory. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Aristides Agramonte, May 23, 1900
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 175 A 1900

Adjutant General's
OFFICE,
JUN 2 1900
ROLLS DIVISION

ORDERS, BOOKS, BLANKS & D.C.
A.G.O.
RECD. JUN 1 1900

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
Havana, May 23, 1900.

1. Under the provisions of paragraph 1, General Orders
No. 24, current series, Headquarters of the Army, the Sub-
sistence Department will commute the rations of Post
Quartermaster Sergeant Norman McLeod, U. S. Army, on
duty at the Post of Guantanamo, Cuba, from and including
June 1, 1900, at the rate of seventy-five (75) cents per
day, it being impracticable to provide for his subsistence in
any other way during the absence of the regular garrison
of that post in summer camp.

2. Hospital Steward Clark L. Brown, U. S. Army, is re-
lieved from duty at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and will re-
port to Major Marlborough C. Wyeth, Surgeon, U. S. Army,
in charge of the Medical Supply Depot, Pirotecnia Militar,
Havana, Cuba, for temporary duty.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. Acting Assistant Surgeon Aristides Agramonte, U. S.
Army, is relieved from duty in the Department of Havana
and Pinar del Rio, and will report to the Chief Surgeon of
the Division, for duty in charge of the Division Laboratory.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:
